raw_text:
Ryanair in $4bn Boeing plane deal
 
 Budget airline Ryanair has placed an order for 70 Boeing 737-800 planes, in a deal valued at $4bn (£2.1bn) which should lead to 2,500 new Ryanair jobs.
 
 It also has an option for a further 70 aircraft, a move which brings the Ryanair/Boeing order book up to 225 firm orders and options on 193 more. Ryanair said the new planes would help it to cut operating costs further. The carrier reported a drop in quarterly profit earlier this year after it was hit by higher fuel costs. However, when it reported the results, the airline was upbeat about prospects for 2005, despite tough competition in the budget airline market.
 
 Ryanair chairman David Bonderman said that the 737-800 had "significantly reduced our unit operating costs and allowed us to reduce air fares each year for the last five years".
 
 "With this new order and new pricing in place, Ryanair expects that unit operating costs (excluding fuel) will continue to fall each year for the next five years," he added. At the end of this year, Ryanair will have taken delivery of about 100 new planes, while the 70 new orders are due for delivery between 2008 and 2012. The airline said that when all these planes have been delivered, it will be able to carry more than 70 million passengers a year, making it Europe's largest airline. About 2,500 new jobs should be created in the next seven years, it added. The order can be seen as good news for Boeing, which in recent years has been overtaken by European plane maker Airbus as the world's biggest-selling plane maker.
llama3.2:1b: Deals will lead to 2,500 new jobs and increase firm orders and options on 193 planes to 225.
The airline expects unit operating costs to fall each year for five years.
Ryanair's chairman says the new order should reduce fuel costs by "significantly".
llama3.2:3b: Ryanair orders 70 Boeing 737-800 planes valued at $4bn to reduce operating costs and create 2,500 new jobs, with options for further 70 aircraft.
The deal is part of a larger order book that should allow Ryanair to carry over 70 million passengers per year and make it Europe's largest airline by 2009.
gemma2:2b: Ryanair placed an order for 70 Boeing 737-800 planes worth $4 billion.
This deal will create 2,500 new jobs and lead to further cost reduction in operating expenses.
The order also includes an option for another 70 aircraft.
The airline expects to achieve a significant increase in passenger capacity upon delivery of all the planes by 2012.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Ryanair is planning to acquire Boeing’s 737-800 aircraft worth $4 billion.
With 250 new jobs created over the next seven years, this order could boost Ryanair's profits and operations in Europe.

Key ideas:
- Ryanair plans to purchase 70 Boeing 737-800 planes
- The deal includes an option for an additional 70 planes 
- This makes the total 250 jobs possible
- The price is $4 billion (£2.1 billion)
- The new planes are expected to reduce operating costs over time
- Ryanair has struggled with low operating costs in recent years, but this order could help improve profitability
Summary: Ryanair has announced plans to purchase Boeing's 737-800 aircraft for about $4 billion, which should lead to the creation of new jobs.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Ryanair orders $4 billion worth of 737-800 planes from Boeing, bringing its total to 225+193 orders/options and securing 2,500 new jobs over seven years, aiming to reduce operating costs further despite fuel price hikes.
Boeing's market share has dropped due to European competitors Airbus.

Ryanair chairman says the new planes will continue to reduce unit operating costs.
Delivery of all planes is expected by 2012, allowing Ryanair to handle over 70 million passengers annually, making it Europe's largest airline.
The order also indicates Boeing's increasing dominance in the aircraft market ahead of Airbus.

However, when it reported the results, the airline was upbeat about prospects for 2005.
Ryanair chairman David Bonderman said that the 737-800 had "significantly reduced our unit operating costs and allowed us to reduce air fares each year for the last five years".
At the end of this year, Ryanair will have taken delivery of about 100 new planes, while the 70 new orders are due for delivery between 2008 and 2012.
The airline said that when all these planes have been delivered, it will be able to carry more than 70 million passengers a year, making it Europe's largest airline.
About 2,500 new jobs should be created in the next seven years, it added.

The airline also has a move to place an option for another 70 aircraft, increasing its order book and options to production.
These deals are expected to further reduce operating costs over the next five years.
Ryanair reported a profit drop due to higher fuel costs but expects positive outlook in 2005 amid tough budget competition.

By the time all planes are delivered, Ryanair aims to carry over 70 million passengers annually, creating approximately 2,500 new jobs in the next seven years.

tinyllama:1.1b: Ryanair has announced an agreement worth $4bn (£2.1bn) with Boeing to purchase 70 new 737-800 planes, which should bring down operating costs further for the budget airline operator.
The order was placed in a deal value of $4bn and could lead to around 2,500 new Ryanair jobs.
This new aircraft order is part of an overall plan by the airline to cut costs further.
Ryanair had been hit by higher fuel costs due to competing with lower fares from the budget airline market in Europe.
However, despite this, the airline was still upbeat about its prospects for 2005 and was expecting that unit operating costs would continue to fall each year for the next five years.
The new order is part of a plan by Ryanair to take delivery of around 100 new planes over the next seven years, with deliveries expected between 2008 and 2012.
This will create an estimated total of around 2,500 jobs for the aircraft maker, making it one of Europe's largest aviation companies.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Ryanair has placed an $4bn Boeing 737-800 order with options to purchase a further 70 aircraft, a move that should lead to over 2,500 new Ryanair jobs and the creation of up to 100 new planes for delivery between 2008 and 2012.
The airline also has an option for a further 70 aircraft, which could bring the total order book up to 225 firm orders and options on 193 more planes, according to Ryanair chairman David Bonderman.
With this new order and new pricing in place, Ryanair is expected to continue to cut unit operating costs (excluding fuel) and reduce air fares each year for the next five years.
At the end of this year, Ryanair will have taken delivery of about 100 new planes, while the 70 new orders are due for delivery between 2008 and 2012.
The airline stated that when all these planes have been delivered, it will be able to carry more than 70 million passengers a year, making it Europe's largest airline.
Additionally, about 2,500 new jobs should be created in the next seven years as a result of this order.
The order can be seen as good news for Boeing and a further sign that Europe's aviation industry is growing rapidly.
